articles.headline: China Further Tightens Grip on the Internet
articles.snippet: The Chinese authorities are no longer tolerating the workarounds used by millions of people who rely heavily on less-fettered access to the Internet.
articles.abstract: The Chinese authorities are no longer tolerating the workarounds used by millions of people who rely heavily on less-fettered access to the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Jing Yuechen, the founder of an Internet start-up here in the Chinese capital, has no interest in overthrowing the Communist Party. But these days she finds herself cursing the nation’s smothering cyberpolice as she tries — and fails — to browse photo-sharing websites like Flickr and struggles to stay in touch with the Facebook friends she has made during trips to France, India and Singapore.

articles.headline: Medicare Payments Surge for Stents to Unblock Blood Vessels in Limbs
articles.snippet: Some cardiologists are reaping huge reimbursements for operating to relieve blockages in peripheral veins and arteries, a treatment many may not need.
articles.abstract: Some cardiologists are reaping huge reimbursements for operating to relieve blockages in peripheral veins and arteries, a treatment many may not need.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time of increasing scrutiny of procedures to open blocked heart arteries, cardiologists are turning to — and reaping huge payments from -- controversial techniques that relieve blockages in the arms and legs.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Google Revenue Is Higher, but Profit Misses Expectations
articles.snippet: The company’s results were squeezed by a number of temporary factors, including a strong dollar that ate into overseas sales.
articles.abstract: The company’s results were squeezed by a number of temporary factors, including a strong dollar that ate into overseas sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Everybody knows Google is working on a lot of things besides search. Wall Street wants to know when all those projects will start making a lot of money.

articles.headline: How, and Why, Apple Overtook Microsoft
articles.snippet: With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple’s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft’s $338 billion.
articles.abstract: With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple’s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft’s $338 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Microsoft stock was at a record high in 1999, and its market capitalization was nearly $620 billion, the notion that Apple Computer would ever be bigger — let alone twice as big — was laughable. Apple was teetering on bankruptcy. And Microsoft’s operating system was so dominant in personal computers, then the center of the technology universe, that the government deemed the company an unlawful monopoly.

articles.headline: Greece’s Feisty Finance Minister Tries a More Moderate Message
articles.snippet: Yanis Varoufakis, a self-described “erratic Marxist,” says that renegotiating Greek debt needn’t be a “yes or no, take it or leave it” situation.
articles.abstract: Yanis Varoufakis, a self-described “erratic Marxist,” says that renegotiating Greek debt needn’t be a “yes or no, take it or leave it” situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In the first days after the election victory of the leftist party Syriza in Greece, Yanis Varoufakis, the new finance minister, has lobbed some rhetorical grenades, referring to his country’s foreign-imposed austerity budgets as “fiscal waterboarding” and calling Greece’s international bailout deals “a toxic mistake.”

articles.headline: Oil Cash Waning, Venezuelan Shelves Lie Bare
articles.snippet: Because Venezuela is so dependent on oil sales to buy imports of food, medicine and many other basics, the drop in oil prices means that there is even less hard currency to buy what the country needs.
articles.abstract: Because Venezuela is so dependent on oil sales to buy imports of food, medicine and many other basics, the drop in oil prices means that there is even less hard currency to buy what the country needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Mary Noriega heard there would be chicken.

articles.headline: ConocoPhillips and Occidental Post Losses, Reflecting Oil Price Plunge
articles.snippet: After years of the industry making record profits both companies said that they lost money in the fourth quarter.
articles.abstract: After years of the industry making record profits both companies said that they lost money in the fourth quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After years of making record profits as oil prices soared, America’s oil giants are beginning to lose money.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Law Firm Founds Project to Fight ‘Revenge Porn’
articles.snippet: K&L Gates has set up the Cyber Civil Rights Legal Project to fight the shame-posting of sexual photos and videos online by jilted lovers.
articles.abstract: K&L Gates has set up the Cyber Civil Rights Legal Project to fight the shame-posting of sexual photos and videos online by jilted lovers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A California law student and a Virginia man dated for about six months after meeting through an online dating service. The fallout from the breakup, however, has gone on far longer, as the former boyfriend faces federal criminal charges over posting nude selfies and a sexually explicit video of the woman on pornographic websites.

articles.headline: Drones Spotted, but Not Halted, Raise Concerns
articles.snippet: Thwarting drones is increasingly becoming a challenge for law enforcement and security officials who are charged with protecting large-scale events like the Super Bowl.
articles.abstract: Thwarting drones is increasingly becoming a challenge for law enforcement and security officials who are charged with protecting large-scale events like the Super Bowl.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Major League Baseball’s top players took the field at the All-Star Game in Minneapolis in July, a covert radar system scanned the sky above the 40,000-seat stadium for what security experts said was an emerging threat to public safety: drones.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Shake Shack, Born in a Park, Is Going Public With Big Dreams
articles.snippet: Shake Shack is part of fast-food movement that has emphasized fresh food and friendliness, a tack that will value the company at around $745 million.
articles.abstract: Shake Shack is part of fast-food movement that has emphasized fresh food and friendliness, a tack that will value the company at around $745 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 14 years ago, on something of a lark, the restaurateur Danny Meyer opened a Chicago-style hot dog cart in Manhattan’s Madison Square Park, hoping to draw crowds to the park and give summer jobs to the staff at one of his nearby high-end restaurants.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Kim Severson

articles.headline: Growth Rate Put at 2.6% as Economy Pulls Ahead
articles.snippet: The American gross domestic product for the fourth quarter was 2.6 percent, a sign of relative health in the economy.
articles.abstract: The American gross domestic product for the fourth quarter was 2.6 percent, a sign of relative health in the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Powered by healthy spending from increasingly optimistic consumers, the American economy is emerging as an island of relative strength in the face of renewed torpor and turmoil elsewhere in much of the world.

articles.headline: Most Republicans Say They Back Climate Action, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: A poll found that about half of Republicans would favor a presidential candidate who supports fighting climate change.
articles.abstract: A poll found that about half of Republicans would favor a presidential candidate who supports fighting climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An overwhelming majority of the American public, including half of Republicans, support government action to curb global warming, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times, Stanford University and the nonpartisan environmental research group Resources for the Future.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Support Waning, Romney Decides Against 2016 Bid
articles.snippet: By not pursuing a third presidential bid, Mitt Romney frees up scores of donors and operatives who had been awaiting his decision.
articles.abstract: By not pursuing a third presidential bid, Mitt Romney frees up scores of donors and operatives who had been awaiting his decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a ski lift high above the powdery slopes of Deer Valley, Utah, Mitt Romney made it clear: His quest for the White House, which had dominated nearly a decade of his life, was coming to a close.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Martin
